text:
Riverside Drive at 122nd St., looking north.
B. Hufnagel, photographer  April 5, 1879
William J. McAlpine, supervising engineer  Apr. 15, 1879 Deposited with NYPL by NYC Park Dept. 1931

Riverside Park at W. 122nd Street and Riverside Drive. Shown is the temporary tomb of General U. S. Grant. The permanent structure was located about one-half block to the north and directly opposite 123rd Street. See: "Sketch of the life of General U. S. Grant" compiled by Col. John J. Garnett, with programme of the Ceremonies of the Dedication of the Grant Monument in New York, April 27, 1897. A. N. p. v 156

About 1885-90

Official photograph, Copyrighted, for the benefit of "Grant Monument Association:" Carvalho, photo Gift of Urbrock Collection

RIVERSIDE PARK.

Riverside Drive, between West 122nd and 123rd Streets. Shown is the temporary tomb of General U.S. Grant, at Riverside Park, completed August 7, 1885. This photograph was taken August 9, 1885, by Mr. Howard Brown. The original negative is now (1936) owned by Mr. Louis Brown (brother), 417 Liberty Street, Newburgh, N.Y. Mr. J.B. Niland, 1844 Arthur Ave., N.Y. City, has a copy of the negative, from which this print was made on October 29, 1936. The present (1936) tomb is 1/2 block farther north, directly opposite 123rd Street. For an account of the burial, See "Sketch of the life of General U.S. Grant, compiled by Col. John J. Garnett, with the Programme of the Ceremonies of the Dedication of the Grant Monument in N.Y., April 27, 1897." A.N. p.v. 156.

August 9, 1885.

Mr. Howard Brown.

RIVERSIDE PARK.

Riverside Drive, west side, from but not including 122nd Street.
About 1890.

Brown Brothers.

528 Riverside Drive, east side, between 122nd Street and Tiemann Place (West 127th Street), 1911.
Gift of E. N. Jenks.

Riverside Drive, at West 122nd Street, and showing the tomb of General U.S. Grant. The view is northward as the entrance is on the
south side of the monument.

A closer view, and showing also the eastern side of the tomb.

(3)

(4)
A view similar to No. 2. Note the change from gas lamps to electricity.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.

RIVERSIDE PARK.

(1) Riverside Drive, at West 122nd Street, and showing the tomb of General U.S. Grant, with the Jersey Highlands for a background. This view was photographed from No. 130 Claremont Ave.

March 23, 1916.

(2) The same, and showing a further view north of the tomb.

Riverside Drive at West 122nd to 123rd Streets showing the tomb of General Ulysses Grant.
About 1920.

RIVERSIDE PARK.

Riverside Drive, from 122nd Street, showing the Hudson River and Grant's Tomb.

About 1920.

Ewing Galloway.

486-497 Riverside Drive, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of 122nd Street.

1925.

Brown Brothers.

Riverside Drive, at W. 122nd Street, showing a northerly approach to the Riverside Baptist Church. The photographer is viewing the construction from a point near 120th Street. View 2 shows the completed edifice, as photographed in a southward direction along Claremont Avenue from a point above 122nd Street. The six story Dacona Hall is at the S. W. corner there.

View 1: July 1929
View 2: May 1931

George L. Balgue

folder: 122nd Street and Riverside Drive, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Squatters Colony, Manhattan: A set of 2 views of an unemployed individual perched on the bank of the Hudson River at about West 122nd Street. No.1 of this set is viewed northward and shows also the recreation pier at the foot of St. Clair (West 129th Street), while No. 2 is southward. On the left of the latter appears buildings on the east side of Riverside Drive. Technically, the undeveloped area shown paralleling the river is Riverside Park which today (1938) has been landscaped as a portion of the West Side Development under the auspices of the Park Department

June 2, 1933

P.L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).
title: Squatters Colony at the Hudson River.

title: Squatters Colony at the Hudson River.

text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, west side, at West 122nd Street, showing the Tomb of General U.S. Grant. The body of Grant, hero of the Civil War, to whom General Lee of the Confederacy surrendered at Appomattox, and twice President of the United States, and that of his wife, lie in two caskets on a sunken level within this monument. The Tomb is open to the public and is a major point of interest to visitors to the metropolis. This view is southward from a point in Riverside Park and shows the northern (left) and western (right) sides of the Mausoleum. The towered structure in the background is the Riverside Baptist Church, at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street and the Drive. It is often called the Rockefeller Church; it having been built by the Rockefeller family.
P. L. Sperr.
June 2, 1935.

(2)
The same, but viewed northward and showing the entrance, which is the south side. At the extreme right appears a part of the International House, which is on the east side of the Drive, slightly north of West 122nd Street. It is a unit of Columbia University.
P. L. Sperr.
June 2, 1935.

(3)
The same as view No. 2, as seen from the park which descends the slope to the Hudson River.
August 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Drive (running from left foreground to right background, past the church), east side, south from and including West 122nd Street, showing the Riverside Church (Baptist), at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street. Adjoining the church (left) is No. 620 West 122nd Street, at the S.W. corner of Claremont Ave., known as McGiffert Hall. This view was taken from the esplanade of the Tomb of General U.S. Grant.
1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

(1) Riverside Drive, at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street. This is the location of the Riverside Baptist Church, of which the tower is mainly shown. This view northward, is as seen from in the grounds of Barnard College (Athletic Field on Broadway, at the S.W. corner of West 119th Street). The smaller tower is atop the Administration Building of the Union Theological Seminary, and is located directly at the N.W. corner of Broadway at West 120th Street.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.

(2) The same.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.

(3) A view of the two spires, as seen westward from Broadway at West 120th Street. Partially shown on the left, is Brinckerhoff Hall, occupying the S.W. corner of Broadway at West 120th Street.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.

(1) Riverside Drive, at West 122nd Street, showing the Riverside Baptist Church, at the S.E. corner. General Grant's Tomb, hidden by trees, is directly opposite, and on the west side of the Drive. This view is southward, in which direction the church tower faces. Shown on the right, are portions of the Union Theological Seminary.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.

(2) A closer view. The 7-story building adjoining the church, is Mc Griffert Hall, a unit of Union Theological Seminary, and is located at the S.W. corner of West 122nd Street and Claremont Ave.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.

(3) A view similar to No. 2. Shown on the right, is the Jersey shore line, as seen across the Hudson River.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.

Riverside Drive, south from a point slightly north of West 122nd Street, showing, on the right, the Tomb of General U.S. Grant, in which the great Civil War hero and President of the U.S. with his wife, lie in two stone caskets on a sunken level open to public view; and on the left; Riverside Church (Baptist), at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street. Contiguous to the latter is, the 7-story McGiffert Hall Building, at the S.W. corner of Claremont Ave. (extreme left). On the east side of Claremont Ave. are seen several low units of Union Theological Seminary. The Hudson River and the shore of the state of New Jersey appear on the right.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd January 13, 1945

Riverside Church
Riverside Drive & 122nd St.

Photograph of Ewing Galloway, N.Y.
WHY CHURCHES GO SKYSCRAPER

In small communities the church is often a landmark with its spires the tallest structure. To retain this rank in the city it must outdo its architectural rivals. This feat is attempted by the new $4,000,000 Riverside Church (commonly called the Rockefeller Church) of which Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick will be pastor.
Riverside Church.
Grant's Tomb
